title.narrative: Access to justice for vulnerable people

description.narrative: The national partners, such as Bar Associations, lawyers and NGOs contribute to ASF projects with their expertise and ability. As ASF seeks to strengthen the capacities of its partners (organising technical training, sharing tools, analyses, lessons learned) and help them to become more effective in their action and more autonomous in view of the sustainability of projects, Bar Associations, lawyers and NGOs are also intended to be beneficiaries. ASF promotes lawyers as key-players and lever for change and therefore raises the awareness of the legal profession about its social role. Throughout the programme period, it is expected that vulnerable people will gain awareness of their rights, an understanding of how to exercise them and benefit from quality advice and assistance when their rights are not respected. Partners will gain technical knowledge, awareness of their respective social role and responsibility toward the most vulnerable, as well as knowhow in providing access to justice. ;

Through its access to justice activities for vulnerable people in post conflict and fragile situations, ASF aims at contributing to the establishment of the rule of law in which the law and the institutions serve society’s most vulnerable groups. ASF’s definition of vulnerability includes “all the people whose rights run the risk of not being defended properly, for whom access to law and justice is extremely limited or for whom law and justice so far, are oppression factors”. ASF contribution to the rule of law starts from the point of view of the vulnerable and poor people. ASF wants to ensure that the creation or reinforcement of the rule of law in the fragile contexts will benefit them and not penalise them. ASF concentrates its actions on providing access to justice for vulnerable people, improving legal aid mechanisms, enhancing local actors’ capacities to answer legal assistance needs and working on better normative frameworks. This approach requires long term engagement for effective capacity building and transfer of expertise. In every area of intervention, ASF identifies target groups as being the most vulnerable depending on the circumstances (e.g. in DRC, women, children, prisoners in pre–trial detention, and victims of international crimes) and adapts its projects to address each group’s specific needs. ;

With the PPA ASF will scale up its key areas of work, such as: - Provision of legal aid (mechanisms) for vulnerable people through expanding delivery of services and strengthening service delivery capacities of ASF partners; - Quality improvement of services delivered from national and international lawyers; e.g. through better evaluation, training and coaching - Legal protection for vulnerable people through advocacy work and networking. These will be achieved through: the expansion of activities, continuous improvement of methodologies and geographical expansion. Mainstreaming of gender will also be scaled up and expanded into researching and identifying new specific legal answers to women’s needs. The main new area of work that will be introduced thanks to the PPA concerns economic and social rights where violations and abuses (including those of companies) remain widely unpunished. Targeting the abuses committed by companies is directly linked to a logic of poverty reduction, in particular because it allows local populations to recover their rights and to engage the responsibility of the States. Civil society in fragile states is poorly informed and lacks the necessary expertise to know their rights. The possibility of finding national experts able to give legal advice or even to take a case before the courts is extremely scarce. The support of ASF has already been requested in DRC on a few cases of non-compliance with national and international legislation in relation to exploitation of natural resources and violations of the rights of native populations ;
